And sometimes one of the kindest acts [you]91-hilary can do to [a fellow - creature]4210-a fellow - creature — one that touches and softens [his]4210-a fellow - creature heart , nay , perhaps wins it to [you]91-hilary for life , is to accept a favor from [him]4210-a fellow - creature . "[91-hilary] [Hilary]91-hilary made no reply . " [I]91-hilary speak a little from experience . [I]91-hilary have not had a very happy life [myself]91-hilary ; at least [most people]875-most people would say so if [they]875-most people knew it ; but [the Lord]3119-the lord has made it up to [me]91-hilary by giving [me]91-hilary the means of bringing happiness , in money as well as other ways , to [other people]560-other people . [Most of [us]4215-us]393-most of us have [our]4215-us favorite luxuries ; this is [mine]91-hilary . [I]91-hilary like to do [people]3210-people good ; [I]91-hilary like , also — though maybe that is a mean weakness — to feel that [I]91-hilary do it . If [all whom [I]91-hilary have been made instrumental in helping]4217-all whom i have been made instrumental in helping had said to [me]91-hilary , as [you]91-hilary have done , ' [I]91-hilary will not be helped , [I]91-hilary will not be made happy , ' it would have been rather hard for [me]91-hilary . "[91-hilary] And a smile , half humorous , half sad , came over the hard - featured face , spiritualizing its whole expression . [Hilary]91-hilary wavered . [She]91-hilary compared [her]91-hilary own life , happy still , and hopeful , for all its cares , with that of [this lonely woman , whose only blessing was [her]91-hilary riches , except the generous heart which sanctified [them]2483-them , and made [them]2483-them such]2482-this lonely woman , whose only blessing was her riches , except the generous heart which sanctified them , and made them such . Humbled , nay , ashamed , [she]91-hilary took and kissed the kindly hand which has succored so many , yet which , in the inscrutable mystery of [Providence]213-providence , had been left to go down to the grave alone ; missing all that is personal , dear , and precious to [a woman]669-a woman 's heart , and getting instead only what [Hilary]91-hilary now gave [her]91-hilary — the half - sweet , half - bitter payment of gratitude . " Well , [[my]91-hilary bairn]4218-my bairn , what is to be done ? "[91-hilary] " [I]91-hilary will do whatever [you]4218-my bairn think right , "[91-hilary] murmured [Hilary]91-hilary . It was not a cheerful morning on which to be married . A dense , yellow , [London]1-london fog , the like of which [the Misses Leaf]89-the misses leaf had never yet seen , penetrated into every corner of [the parlor]313-the parlor at [No . 15]1304-no . 15 , where [they]2487-they were breakfasting drearily by candle - light , all in [their]2487-they wedding attire . [They]2487-they had been up since six in morning , and [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth had dressed [[her]94-elizabeth three mistresses]272-her three mistresses one after the other , taking exceeding pleasure in the performance . For [she]94-elizabeth was still little more than [a girl , to whom a wedding was a wedding]2489-a girl , to whom a wedding was a wedding , and this was the first [she]94-elizabeth had ever had to do with in [her]94-elizabeth life . True , it disappointed [her]94-elizabeth in some things . [She]94-elizabeth was a little surprised that last evening had passed off just like all other evenings . The interest and bustle of packing soon subsided — the packing consisting only of the traveling trunk , for the rest of the trousseau went straight to [Russell Square]3-russell square , every means having been taken to ignore the very existence of No . 15 ; and then [the three ladies]3254-the three ladies had supper as usual , and went to bed at [their]3254-the three ladies customary hour without any special demonstrations of emotion of affection . To [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth this was strange . [She]94-elizabeth had not yet learned the unspeakable bitterness of a parting where [no body]3909-no body has any grief to restrain . On a wedding morning , of course , there is no time to be spared for sentiment . The principal business appeared to be — dressing . [Mr. Ascott]97-ascott had insisted on doing [his]97-ascott part in making [his]97-ascott new connections appear " respectable "[97-ascott] at [his]97-ascott marriage , and for [Selina]92-selina 's sake [they]3254-the three ladies had consented . Indeed , it was inevitable : [they]3254-the three ladies had no money whatever to clothe [themselves]3254-the three ladies withal . [They]3254-the three ladies must either have accepted [Mr. Ascott]97-ascott 's gifts — in which , to do [him]97-ascott justice , [he]97-ascott was both thoughtful and liberal — or [they]3254-the three ladies must have staid away from the wedding altogether , which [they]3254-the three ladies did not like to do " for the sake of [the family]258-the family . "[3254-the three ladies] So , with a sense of doing [their]3254-the three ladies last duty by [the sister]2492-the sister , who would be , [they]3254-the three ladies felt , henceforward [a sister]2493-a sister no more , [Miss Leaf]92-selina attired [herself]92-selina in [her]92-selina violet silk and white China shawl , and [Miss Hilary]91-hilary put on [her]91-hilary silver - grey poplin , with a cardinal cape , as was then in fashion , trimmed with white swan's - down . It was rather an elderly costume for [a bridemaid]2494-a bridemaid ; but [she]92-selina was determined to dress warmly , and not risk , in muslins and laces , the health which to [her]92-selina now was money , life — nay , honor . For [[Ascott]97-ascott 's creditor]2495-ascott 's creditor had been already paid : [Miss Balquidder]168-miss balquidder never let grass grow under [her]168-miss balquidder feet . When [Hilary]91-hilary returned to [[her]91-hilary sisters]302-her sisters that day there was no longer any fear of public exposure ; [she]91-hilary had the receipted bill in [her]91-hilary hand , and [she]91-hilary was [[Miss Balquidder]168-miss balquidder 's debtor]2497-miss balquidder 's debtor to the extent of eighty pounds . But it was no debt of disgrace or humiliation , nor did [she]91-hilary feel it as such . [She]91-hilary had learned the lesson which [the large hearted rich]2498-the large hearted rich can always teach [the poor]1105-the poor , that , while there is sometimes , to [some people , no more galling chain]2500-some people , no more galling chain , there is to [others]525-others — and these are the highest natures , too — no more firm and sacred bond than gratitude . But still the debt was there ; and [Hilary]91-hilary would never feel quite easy till it was paid — in money , at least . The generosity [she]91-hilary never wished to repay . [She]91-hilary would rather feel it wrapping [her]91-hilary round , like an arm that was heavy only through its exceeding tenderness , to the end of [her]91-hilary days . Nevertheless [she]91-hilary had arranged that there was to be a regular monthly deduction from [her]91-hilary salary ; and how , by retrenchment , to make this monthly payment as large as [she]91-hilary could , was a question which had occupied [herself]91-hilary and [Johanna]93-johanna for a good while after [they]2502-they had retired to rest . For there was no time to be lost . [Mrs. Jones]153-mrs. jones must be given notice to ; and there was another notice to be given , if the Richmond plan were carried out ; another sad retrenchment , foreboding which , when [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth brought up supper , [Miss Hilary]91-hilary could hardly look [the girl]307-the girl in the face , and , when [she]91-hilary bade [her]91-hilary good night , had felt almost like [a secret conspirator]2504-a secret conspirator . For [she]91-hilary knew that , if the money to clear this debt was to be saved , [they]2502-they must part with [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth . No doubt the personal sacrifice would be considerable , for [Hilary]91-hilary would have to do the work of [[their]2502-they two rooms]2505-their two rooms with [her]91-hilary own hands , and give up a hundred little comforts in which [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , now become [a most clever and efficient servant]2506-a most clever and efficient servant , had made [herself]94-elizabeth necessary to [them]2502-they both . But [the two ladies]2507-the two ladies did not think of that at the moment ; [they]2507-the two ladies only thought of the pain of parting with [her]91-hilary . [They]2502-they thought of it sorely , even though [she]91-hilary was but [a servant]246-a servant , and there was [a family parting close at hand]2509-a family parting close at hand . Alas ! [people]3210-people must take what [they]3210-people earn . It was a melancholy fact that , of the two impending losses , [the person [they]2502-they should miss most]2511-the person they should miss most would be , not [[their]2502-they sister]1795-their sister , but [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth . Both regrets combined made [them]2502-they sit at the breakfast table — the last meal [they]2502-they should ever take together as [a family]1054-a family — sad and sorry , speaking about little else than the subject which presented itself as easiest and uppermost , namely , clothes . Finally , [they]2502-they stood all completely arrayed , even to bonnets ; [Hilary]91-hilary looking wonderfully bewitching in [hers]91-hilary , which was the very pattern of one that may still be seen in a youthful portrait of [[our]2514-our gracious Queen]2515-our gracious queen — a large round brim , with a wreath of roses inside ; while [Miss Leaf]91-hilary 's was somewhat like it , only with little bunches of white ribbon : " for , "[91-hilary] [she]91-hilary said , " [my]91-hilary time of roses has gone by . "[91-hilary] But [her]91-hilary sweet faded face had a peace that was not in the other two — not even in [Hilary]91-hilary 's . But the time arrived ; [the carriage]1127-the carriage drew up at the door . Then nature and sisterly feeling asserted [themselves]2502-they for a minute . [Miss Selina]92-selina " gave way , "[92-selina] not to any loud or indecorous extent , to nothing that could in the least harm [her]92-selina white satin , or crumple [her]92-selina laces and ribbons ; but [she]92-selina did shed a tear or two — real honest tears — kissed [[her]92-selina sisters]302-her sisters affectionately , hoped [they]302-her sisters would be very happy at [Richmond]27-richmond , and that [they]302-her sisters would often come to see [her]92-selina at [Russell Square]3-russell square . " [You]4220-you know , "[92-selina] said [she]92-selina , half apologetically , " it is a great deal better for one of [us]4221-us at least to be married and settled . Indeed [I]92-selina assure [you]4220-you . [I]92-selina have done it all for the good of [[my]92-selina family]3887-my family . "[92-selina] And for the time being [she]92-selina devoutly believed [she]92-selina had . So it was all over . [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth [herself]94-elizabeth , from [the aisle of [St. Pancras Church]55-st. pancras church]2518-the aisle of st. pancras church , watched the beginning and ending of the show ; a very fine show , with a number of [handsomely dressed people]2519-handsomely dressed people , [wedding guests]2520-wedding guests , who seemed to stare about [them]2521-them a good deal and take little interest in either [bride]2522-bride or [bridegroom]2523-bridegroom . [The only persons [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth]2524-the only persons elizabeth recognized were [[her]94-elizabeth mistresses]429-her mistresses — [Miss Leaf]92-selina , who kept [her]92-selina veil down and never stirred ; and [Miss Hilary]91-hilary , who stood close behind [the bride , listening with downcast eyes to the beautiful marriage service]2526-the bride , listening with downcast eyes to the beautiful marriage service . It must have touched [her]92-selina more than on [[her]92-selina sister]559-her sister 's account , for a tear , gathered under each eyelash , silently rolled down the soft cheek and fell . " "[91-hilary] [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's [an angel]2528-an angel , and [he]2529-he 'll be [a lucky man]2530-a lucky man that gets [her]91-hilary , " meditated [[her]94-elizabeth faithful "[2529-he] [bower - maiden " of old]4224-bower - maiden " of old]4223-her faithful " bower - maiden " of old ; as , a little excited by the event of the morning , [she]94-elizabeth stood by the mantle - piece and contemplated a letter which had come after [the ladies]245-the ladies departed ; one of these regular monthly Indian letters , after which , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth was sharp enough to notice , [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's step always grew lighter and [her]91-hilary eye brighter for many days . "[2529-he] It must be a nice thing to have [somebody fond of one]2531-somebody fond of one , and [somebody to be fond of]2532-somebody to be fond of , " meditated [she]94-elizabeth . And "[2532-somebody to be fond of] old fashioned piece of goods " as [she]92-selina was — according to [Mrs. Jones]153-mrs. jones ( who now , from the use [she]153-mrs. jones was in [[the Jones]153-mrs. jones 's menage]4226-the jones 's menage , patronized and confided in [[her]153-mrs. jones extremely]4227-her extremely ) some little bit of womanly craving after [the woman]694-the woman 's one hope and crown of bliss crept into [the poor maid - servant]4229-the poor maid - servant 's heart . But it was not for [the maid - servant]4230-the maid - servant 's usual necessity — a "[2529-he] sweet heart"—somebody to "[4224-bower - maiden " of old] keep company with ; " it was rather for [somebody]3240-somebody to love , and perhaps take care of a little . [People]3210-people love according to [their]3210-people natures ; and [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's was a strong nature ; its principal element being a capacity for passionate devotedness , almost unlimited in extent . [Such women , who love most]4233-such women , who love most , are not always , indeed very rarely , loved best . And so it was perhaps as well that [poor Elizabeth]94-elizabeth should make up [her]94-elizabeth mind , as [she]94-elizabeth did very composedly , that [she]94-elizabeth [herself]94-elizabeth should never be married ; but after that glorious wedding of [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's to [Mr. Lyon]98-robert lyon , should settle down to take care of [Miss Leaf]91-hilary all [her]94-elizabeth days . "[4224-bower - maiden " of old] And if [I]0-i turn out only half as good and contented as [[my]0-i mistress]4128-my mistress , it ca n't be such a dreadful thing to be [an old maid]2534-an old maid after all , " stoically said [Elizabeth Hand]94-elizabeth . The words were scarcely out of [her]94-elizabeth mouth when [her]94-elizabeth attention was caught by some one in the passage inquiring for [her]94-elizabeth ; yes , actually for [her]94-elizabeth . [She]94-elizabeth could hardly believe [her]94-elizabeth eyes when [she]94-elizabeth perceived it was [[her]94-elizabeth new - found old acquaintance]4234-her new - found old acquaintance , [Tom Cliffe]132-tom . [He]132-tom was dressed very well , out of livery ; indeed , [he]132-tom looked so extremely like [a gentleman]3465-a gentleman that [[Mrs. Jones]153-mrs. jones 's little girl]4236-mrs. jones 's little girl took [him]132-tom for one , called [him]132-tom "[3469-sir] [Sir]3469-sir , " and showed [him]132-tom into [the parlor]313-the parlor . "[3469-sir] All right . [I]0-i thought this was [the house]344-the house . Uncommon sharp of [me]0-i to hunt [you]2537-you out ; was n't it [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth ? " But [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth was a little stiff , flurried , and perplexed . [[Her]94-elizabeth mistresses]429-her mistresses were out ; [she]94-elizabeth did not know whether [she]94-elizabeth ought to ask [Tom]132-tom in , especially as it must be into [the parlor]313-the parlor ; there was no other place to take [him]132-tom to . However , [Tom]132-tom settled the matter with a conclusive , "[94-elizabeth] Oh , gammon!"—sat [himself]132-tom down , and made [himself]132-tom quite comfortable . And [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth was so glad to see [him]132-tom — glad to have another chance of talking about [dear old Stowbury]2-stowbury . It could not be wrong ; [she]94-elizabeth would not say a word about , [the family]258-the family , not even tell [him]132-tom [she]94-elizabeth lived with [the Misses Leaf]89-the misses leaf if [she]94-elizabeth could help it . And [Tom]132-tom did not seem in the least curious . "[94-elizabeth] Now , [I]0-i call this quite a coincidence . [I]0-i was stopping at [St. Pancras Church]55-st. pancras church to look at a wedding — [some old city fogy who lives in [Russell Square]3-russell square]2538-some old city fogy who lives in russell square , and is making a great splash ; and there [I]0-i see [you]2539-you , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , standing in [the crowd]1101-the crowd , and looking so nice and spicy — as fresh as an apple and as brisk as a bee . [I]0-i hummed and hawed and whistled , but [I]0-i could n't catch [your]2539-you eye ; then [I]0-i missed [you]2539-you , and was vexed above a bit , till [I]0-i saw one like [you]2539-you going in at this door , so [I]0-i just knocked and asked ; and here [you]2539-you are ! ' Pon [my]0-i life , [I]0-i am very glad to see [you]2539-you . " "[0-i] Thank [you]2539-you , [Tom]132-tom , " said [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , pleased , even grateful for the trouble [he]2539-you had taken about [her]94-elizabeth : [she]94-elizabeth had so [few friends]4241-few friends ; in truth , actually none . [They]4242-they began to talk , and [Tom Cliffe]132-tom talked exceedingly well . [He]132-tom had added to [his]132-tom natural cleverness a degree of London sharpness , the result of much "[132-tom] knocking about " ever since childhood . Besides , [[his]132-tom master]4243-his master , [the literary gentleman]4244-the literary gentleman , who had picked [him]132-tom out of [the printing office]4245-the printing office , had taken a deal of pains with [him]132-tom . [Tom]132-tom was , for [his]132-tom station , [a very intelligent and superior young man]4246-a very intelligent and superior young man . Not [a boy]384-a boy , though [he]132-tom was still under twenty , but [a young man]1903-a young man : that precocity of development which often accompanies a delicate constitution , making [him]132-tom appear , as [he]132-tom was indeed , in mind and character , fully six or seven years older than [his]132-tom real age . [He]132-tom was [a handsome fellow]4249-a handsome fellow , too , though small ; dark haired , dark eyed , with regular and yet sensitive and mobile features . [Altogether Tom Cliffe]132-tom was decidedly interesting , and [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth took great pleasure in looking at [him]132-tom , and in thinking , with a certain half motherly , half romantic satisfaction , that but for [her]94-elizabeth , and [her]94-elizabeth carrying [him]132-tom [home]3045-home from under the horse 's heels , [he]132-tom might , humanly speaking , have been long ago buried in [Stowbury church yard]4251-stowbury church yard . "[0-i] [I]0-i have a ' [church yard]2541-church yard cough ' at times still , " said [he]132-tom , when speaking of this little episode of early life . "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i shall ever live to be [a middle - aged man]2542-a middle - aged man . " And [he]132-tom shook [his]132-tom head , and looked melancholy and poetical ; nay , even showed [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth some poetry that [he]132-tom [himself]132-tom had written on the subject , which was clever enough in its way . [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's interest grew . [An ordinary baker]4252-an ordinary baker or [butcher boy]4253-butcher boy would not have attracted [her]94-elizabeth in the least ; but here was something in the shape of [a hero]664-a hero , somebody who at once touched [her]94-elizabeth sympathies and roused [her]94-elizabeth admiration . For [Tom]132-tom was quite as well informed as [she]94-elizabeth was [herself]94-elizabeth ; more so , indeed . [He]132-tom was [one of [the many shrewd and clever working men who were then beginning to rise up and think for [themselves]4256-the many shrewd and clever working men who were then beginning to rise up and think for themselves , and educate themselves , and educate [themselves]4256-the many shrewd and clever working men who were then beginning to rise up and think for themselves , and educate themselves]4256-the many shrewd and clever working men who were then beginning to rise up and think for themselves , and educate themselves]4255-one of the many shrewd and clever working men who were then beginning to rise up and think for themselves , and educate themselves . [He]132-tom attended classes at [[mechanics]4257-mechanics ' institutions]4258-mechanics ' institutions , and [young men]3489-young men 's debating societies ; where every topic of the day , religion , politics , political economy , was handled freely , as [the young]1636-the young do handle these serious things . [He]132-tom threw [himself]132-tom , heart and soul , into the new movement , which , like all revolutions , had at first its great and fatal dangers , but yet resulted in much good ; clearing the political sky , and bringing all sorts of hidden abuses under the sharp eyes of [that great scourge of evil - doers]4261-that great scourge of evil - doers — public opinion . Yet [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , reared under the wing of the conservative [Misses Leaf]89-the misses leaf , was a little startled when [Tom Cliffe]132-tom , who apparently liked talking and being listened to , gave [her]94-elizabeth a long dissertation on the true principles of the Charter , and how [Frost]190-frost , [Williams]191-williams , and [Jones]153-mrs. jones — names all but forgotten now — were [very ill - used men]4262-very ill - used men , [actual martyrs]4263-actual martyrs . [She]94-elizabeth was more than startled — shocked indeed — until there came a reaction of the deepest pity — when [he]132-tom confessed that [he]132-tom never went to [church]396-church . [He]132-tom saw no use in going , [he]132-tom said ; [the parsons]4265-the parsons were all shams , paid largely to chatter about what [they]4265-the parsons did not understand ; the only real religion was that which [a man]628-a man thought out for [himself]628-a man , and acted out for [himself]628-a man . Which was true enough , though only a half truth ; and [innocent Elizabeth]94-elizabeth did not see [the other half]4267-the other half . But [she]94-elizabeth was touched and carried away by the earnestness and enthusiasm of [the lad]422-the lad , wild , fierce iconoclast as [he]422-the lad was , ready to cast down the whole fabric of Church and State ; though without any personal hankering after lawless rights and low pleasures . [[His]422-the lad sole idol]4269-his sole idol was , as [he]422-the lad said , intellect , and that was [his]422-the lad preservation . Also , the fragile health which was betrayed in every flash of [his]422-the lad eye , every flush of [his]422-the lad sallow cheek , made [Tom Cliffe]132-tom , even in the two hours [he]422-the lad staid with [her]94-elizabeth , come very close to [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's heart . It was such a warm heart , such a liberal heart , thinking so little of itself or of its own value . So here began to be told the old story , familiar in [kitchens]4270-kitchens as [parlors]4271-parlors ; but , from the higher bringing up of [the two parties concerned]4272-the two parties concerned , conducted in this case more after the fashion of [the latter]479-the latter than the former . [Elizabeth Hand]94-elizabeth was [an exceptional person]4274-an exceptional person , and [Tom]132-tom had the sense to see that at once . [He]132-tom paid [her]94-elizabeth no coarse attentions , did not attempt to make love to [her]94-elizabeth ; but [he]132-tom liked [her]94-elizabeth , and [he]132-tom let [her]94-elizabeth see that [he]132-tom did . True , [she]94-elizabeth was not pretty , and [she]94-elizabeth was older than [he]132-tom ; but that to [a boy of nineteen]4275-a boy of nineteen is rather flattering than otherwise . Also , for there is a law even under the blind mystery of likings and fallings in love — a certain weakness in [him]132-tom , that weakness which generally accompanies the poetical nature , clung to the quiet , solid , practical strength of [hers]94-elizabeth . [He]132-tom liked to talk and be listened to by those silent , admiring , gentle gray eyes ; and [he]132-tom thought it very pleasant when , with a motherly prudence , [she]94-elizabeth warned [him]132-tom to be careful over [his]132-tom cough , and gave [him]132-tom a flannel breast - plate to protect [his]132-tom chest against the cold . When [he]132-tom went away [Tom]132-tom was so far in love that , following the free and easy ways of [[his]132-tom class]4276-his class , [he]132-tom attempted to give [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth a kiss ; but [she]94-elizabeth drew back so hotly that [he]132-tom begged [her]94-elizabeth pardon , and slipped away rather confounded . "[2542-a middle - aged man] That 's an odd sort of [young woman]3928-young woman ; there 's something in [her]3928-young woman , " said [he]132-tom to [himself]132-tom . "[3928-young woman] [I]0-i 'll get a kiss , though , by - and - by . " Meanwhile [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , having forgotten all about [her]94-elizabeth dinner , sat thinking , actually doing nothing but thinking , until within half an hour of the time when [[her]94-elizabeth mistresses]429-her mistresses might be expected back . [They]429-her mistresses were to go direct to [the hotel]3605-the hotel , breakfast , wait till [the newly - married couple]4279-the newly - married couple had departed , and then come [home]3045-home . [They]429-her mistresses would be sure to be weary , and want [their]429-her mistresses tea . So [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth made every thing ready for [them]429-her mistresses , steadily putting [Tom Cliffe]132-tom out of [her]94-elizabeth mind . One thing [she]94-elizabeth was glad of , that talking so much about [his]132-tom own affairs , [he]132-tom had forgotten to inquire concerning [hers]94-elizabeth , and was still quite ignorant even of [[her]94-elizabeth mistresses]429-her mistresses ' name . [He]132-tom therefore could tell no tales of [the Leaf family]3219-the leaf family at [Stowbury]2-stowbury . Still [she]94-elizabeth determined at once to inform [Miss Hilary]91-hilary that [he]132-tom had been [here]389-here , but that , if [she]94-elizabeth wished it , [he]132-tom should never come again . And it spoke well for [her]94-elizabeth resolve , that while resolving [she]94-elizabeth was startled to find how very sorry [she]94-elizabeth should feel if [Tom Cliffe]132-tom never came again . [I]0-i know [I]0-i am painting [this young woman with a strangely tender conscience , a refinement of feeling , and a general moral sensitiveness]4284-this young woman with a strangely tender conscience , a refinement of feeling , and a general moral sensitiveness which [people]3210-people say is seldom or never to be found in [her]94-elizabeth rank of life . And why not ? Because [mistresses]829-mistresses treat [servants]1052-servants as [servants]1052-servants , and not as [women]3061-women ; because in the sharp , hard line [they]829-mistresses draw , at the outset , between [themselves]829-mistresses and [[their]829-mistresses domestics]4290-their domestics , [they]829-mistresses give no chance for any womanliness to be developed . And therefore since human nature is weak , and without help from without , [a long degraded class]4291-a long degraded class can never rise , sweet - hearts will still come crawling through back entries and down at area doors ; [mistresses]829-mistresses will still have to dismiss helpless and fallen , or brazen in iniquity , many [a wretched girl who once was innocent]4293-a wretched girl who once was innocent ; or , if nothing actually vicious results , may have many [a good , respectable servant]4294-a good , respectable servant , who left to get married , return , complaining that [[her]94-elizabeth "[0-i] young man , " whom [she]94-elizabeth knew so little about]4295-her " young man , " whom she knew so little about , has turned out [a drunken scoundrel of [a husband]353-a husband , who drives [her]94-elizabeth back to [[her]94-elizabeth old comfortable "[0-i] place]4298-her old comfortable " place " to beg for [herself]94-elizabeth and [[her]94-elizabeth starving babies]4299-her starving babies a morsel of bread]4296-a drunken scoundrel of a husband , who drives her back to her old comfortable " place " to beg for herself and her starving babies a morsel of bread . When , with a vivid blush that [she]94-elizabeth could not repress , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth told [[her]94-elizabeth mistress]431-her mistress that [Tom Cliffe]132-tom had been to see [her]94-elizabeth , [the latter]479-the latter replied at first carelessly , for [her]94-elizabeth mind was preoccupied . Then , [her]94-elizabeth attention caught by the aforesaid blush , [Miss Hilary]91-hilary asked . "[422-the lad] How old is [the lad]422-the lad ? " "[422-the lad] Nineteen . " "[422-the lad] That 's a bad age , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth . Too old to be [a pet]2545-a pet , and rather too young for [a husband]353-a husband . " "[0-i] [I]0-i never thought of such a thing , " said [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , warmly — and honestly , at the time . "[0-i] Did [he]422-the lad want to come and see [you]2547-you again ? " "[422-the lad] [He]422-the lad said so . " "[422-the lad] Oh , well , if [he]422-the lad is [a steady , respectable lad]2548-a steady , respectable lad there can be no objection . [I]0-i should like to see [him]422-the lad [myself]0-i next time . " And then a sudden sharp recollection that there would likely be no next time , in [their]4302-they service at least , made [Miss Hilary]91-hilary feel quite a hypocrite . "[94-elizabeth] [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , " said [she]0-i , "[94-elizabeth] [we]2549-we will speak about [Tom Cliffe]132-tom — is not that [his]422-the lad name?—by - and - by . Now , as soon as tea is over , [[my]0-i sister]3017-my sister wants to talk to [you]94-elizabeth . When [you]94-elizabeth are ready , will [you]94-elizabeth come up [stairs]3048-stairs ? " [She]0-i spoke in an especially gentle tone , so that by no possibility could [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth fancy [they]4302-they were displeased with [her]0-i . Now , knowing the circumstances of [the family]258-the family , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's conscience had often smitten [her]94-elizabeth that [she]94-elizabeth must eat a great deal , that [her]94-elizabeth wages , paid regularly month by month , must make a great hole in [[her]94-elizabeth mistress]431-her mistress 's income . [She]94-elizabeth was , alack ! a sad expense , and [she]94-elizabeth tried to lighten [her]94-elizabeth cost in every possible way . But it never struck [her]94-elizabeth that [they]4302-they could do without [her]94-elizabeth , or that any need would arise for [their]4302-they doing so . So [she]94-elizabeth went into [the parlor]313-the parlor quite unsuspiciously , and found [Miss Leaf]91-hilary lying on the sofa , and [Miss Hilary]91-hilary reading aloud the letter from [India]11-india . But it was laid quietly aside as [she]94-elizabeth said , "[93-johanna] [Johanna]93-johanna , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth is here . " Then [Johanna]93-johanna , rousing [herself]93-johanna to say what must be said , but putting it as gently and kindly as [she]93-johanna could , told [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , what [mistresses]829-mistresses often think it below [their]829-mistresses dignity to tell to [servants]1052-servants , the plain truth — namely , that circumstances obliged [herself]94-elizabeth and [Miss Hilary]91-hilary to retrench [their]4302-they expenses as much as [they]4302-they possibly could . That [they]4302-they were going to live in [two little rooms at [Richmond]27-richmond]4308-two little rooms at richmond , where [they]4302-they would board with [the inmates of [the house]344-the house]4309-the inmates of the house . "[94-elizabeth] And so , and so — " [Miss Leaf]91-hilary faltered . It was very hard to say it with those eager eyes fixed upon [her]94-elizabeth . [Hilary]91-hilary took up the word — "[94-elizabeth] And so , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , much as it grieves [us]2552-we , [we]2552-we shall be obliged to part with [you]94-elizabeth . [We]2552-we can not any longer afford to keep [a servant]246-a servant . " No answer . "[246-a servant] It is not even as it was once before , when [we]2552-we thought [you]94-elizabeth might do better for [yourself]94-elizabeth . [We]2552-we know , if it were possible , [you]94-elizabeth would rather stay with [us]2552-we , and [we]2552-we would rather keep [you]94-elizabeth . It is like parting with [one of [[our]2552-we own family]2555-our own family]2554-one of our own family . " And [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's voice too failed . "[2552-we] However , there is no help for it ; [we]2552-we must part . " [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , recovered from [her]94-elizabeth first bewildered grief , was on the point of bursting out into entreaties that [she]94-elizabeth might do like [many another faithful servant]4311-many another faithful servant , live without wages , put up with any hardships , rather than be sent away . But something in [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's manner told [her]94-elizabeth it would be useless — worse than useless , painful : and [she]94-elizabeth would do any thing rather than give [[her]94-elizabeth mistress]431-her mistress pain . When , utterly unable to control it , [she]94-elizabeth gave vent to one loud sob , the expression of acute suffering on [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's countenance was such that [she]94-elizabeth determined to sob no more . [She]94-elizabeth felt that , for some reason or other , the thing was inevitable ; that [she]94-elizabeth must take up [her]94-elizabeth burden , as [[her]94-elizabeth mistress]431-her mistress had done , even though it were the last grief of all — leaving [that beloved mistress]4314-that beloved mistress . "[2552-we] That 's right , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , " said [Miss Hilary]91-hilary , softly . "[94-elizabeth] All these changes are very bitter to [us]2556-we also , but [we]2556-we bear them . There is nothing lasting in [this world]1916-this world , except doing right , and being good and faithful and helpful to [one another]394-one another . " [She]91-hilary sighed . Possibly there had been sad tidings in the letter which [she]91-hilary still held in [her]91-hilary hand , clinging to it as [we]2556-we do to something which , however sorely it hurts [us]2556-we , [we]2556-we would not part with for [the whole world]361-the whole world . But there was no hopelessness or despair in [her]91-hilary tone , and [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth caught the influence of that true courageous heart . "[2559-you] Perhaps [you]2559-you may be able to take [me]0-i back again soon , [Ma'am]192-ma'am , " said [she]0-i , looking toward [Miss Leaf]91-hilary . "[2559-you] And meantime [I]0-i might get a place ; [Mrs. Jones]153-mrs. jones has told [me]0-i of several ; " and [she]0-i stopped , afraid lest it might be found out how often [Mrs. Jones]153-mrs. jones had urged [her]0-i to "[153-mrs. jones] better [herself]0-i , " and [she]0-i had indignantly refused . "[0-i] Or , " ( a bright idea occurred ) "[0-i] [I]0-i wonder if [Miss Selina]92-selina , that is , [Mrs. Ascott]99-ascott , would take [me]0-i in at [Russell Square]3-russell square ? " [Hilary]91-hilary looked hard at [her]0-i . "[92-selina] Would [you]0-i really like that ? " "[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i should ; for [I]0-i should see and hear of [you]0-i . [Miss Hilary]91-hilary , if [you]91-hilary please , [I]0-i wish [you]91-hilary would ask [Mrs. Ascott]99-ascott to take [me]0-i . " And [Hilary]91-hilary , much surprised — for [she]91-hilary was well acquainted with [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's sentiments toward both [Mr. Ascott]97-ascott and [the late Miss Selina—-promised]193-the late miss selina—-promised . And now [I]99-ascott leave [Miss Hilary]91-hilary for a time ; leave [her]91-hilary in , if not happiness , great peace . Peace which , after these stormy months , was an actual paradise of calm to both [herself]91-hilary and [Johanna]93-johanna . [Their]4316-they grief for [Ascott]97-ascott had softened down . Its very hopelessness gave it resignation . There was nothing more to be done ; [they]4316-they had done all [they]4316-they could , both to find [him]97-ascott out and to save [him]97-ascott from the public disgrace which might blight any hope of reformation . Now the result must be left in higher hands . Only at times fits of restless trouble would come ; times when a sudden knock at the door would make [Johanna]93-johanna shake nervously for minutes afterward ; when [Hilary]91-hilary walked about every where with [her]91-hilary mind preoccupied , and [her]91-hilary eyes open to notice [every chance passerby]4317-every chance passerby ; nay , [she]91-hilary had sometimes secretly followed down [a whole street]4318-a whole street some figure which , in its light jaunty step and long fashionably - cut hair , reminded [her]91-hilary of [Ascott]97-ascott . Otherwise [they]4316-they were not unhappy , [she]91-hilary and [[her]91-hilary dearest sister]4319-her dearest sister . Poor as [they]4316-they were , [they]4316-they were together , and [their]4316-they poverty had no sting . [They]4316-they knew exactly how much [they]4316-they would receive monthly , and how much [they]4316-they ought to spend . Though obliged to calculate every penny , still [their]4316-they income and expenses were alike certain ; there was no anxiety about money matters , which of itself was an indescribable relief . Also there was that best blessing — peace at [home]3045-home . Never in all [her]91-hilary days had [Johanna]93-johanna known such an easy life ; sitting quietly in [[her]91-hilary parlor]4321-her parlor while [Hilary]91-hilary was engaged in [the shop below]4322-the shop below ; descending to dinner , where [she]91-hilary took the head of the table , and [the young people]4323-the young people soon learned to treat [her]91-hilary with great respect and even affection ; then waiting for the happy tea in [[their]4323-the young people own room]4324-their own room , and the walk afterward , in [Richmond Park]56-richmond park or along [the Thames banks]4325-the thames banks toward [Twickenham]57-twickenham . Perhaps it was partly from the contrast to that weary year in [London]1-london , but never , in any spring , had the air seemed so balmy , or the trees so green . [They]4316-they brought back to [Hilary]91-hilary 's face the youthful bloom which [she]91-hilary had begun to lose ; and , in degree , [her]91-hilary youthful brightness , which had also become slightly overclouded . Again [she]91-hilary laughed and made [her]91-hilary little domestic jokes , and regained [her]91-hilary pretty ways of putting things , so that every thing always appeared to have a cheerful , and comical , side . Also — for while [we]4326-we are made as [we]4326-we are , with capacity for happiness , and especially the happiness of love , it is sure to be thus — [she]91-hilary had a little private sunbeam in [her]91-hilary own heart , which brightened outside things . After that sad letter from [India]11-india which came on [Selina]92-selina 's wedding day , [every succeeding one]4327-every succeeding one grew more cheerful , more demonstrative , nay , even affectionate ; though still with that queer Scotch pride of [his]4328-his , that would ask for nothing till it could ask and have every thing , and give every thing in return — the letters were all addressed to [Johanna]93-johanna . "[99-ascott] What an advantage it is to be [an old woman]3726-an old woman ! " [Miss Leaf]92-selina would sometimes say , mischievously , when [she]92-selina received them . But more often [she]92-selina said nothing , waiting in peace for events to develop themselves . [She]92-selina did not think much about [herself]92-selina , and had no mean jealousy over [[her]92-selina child]3364-her child ; [she]92-selina knew that a righteous and holy love only makes all natural affections more sacred and more dear . And [Hilary]91-hilary ? [She]91-hilary held [her]91-hilary head higher and prouder ; and the spring trees looked greener , and [the river]4330-the river ran brighter in the sunshine . Ah , Heaven pity [us]4331-us all ! it is a good thing to have love in [one]585-one 's life ; it is a good thing , if only for a time , to be actually happy . Not merely contented , but happy ! And so [I]3726-an old woman will leave [her]91-hilary , [this little woman]4333-this little woman ; and [nobody]357-nobody need mourn over [her]91-hilary because [she]91-hilary is working too hard , or pity [her]91-hilary because [she]91-hilary is obliged to work ; has to wear common clothes , and live in [narrow rooms]4335-narrow rooms , and pass on [her]91-hilary poor weary feet the grand carriages of [the Richmond gentry]4336-the richmond gentry , who are not a bit more well - born or well - educated than [she]91-hilary ; who never take the least notice of [her]91-hilary , except sometimes to peer curious at the desk where [she]91-hilary sits in [the shop - corner]4337-the shop - corner , and wonder who "[3726-an old woman] [that young person with the rather pretty curls]2561-that young person with the rather pretty curls " can be . No matter , [she]91-hilary is happy . How much happiness was there in [the large house at [Russell Square]3-russell square]4338-the large house at russell square ? [The Misses Leaf]89-the misses leaf could not tell ; [[their]89-the misses leaf sister]1795-their sister never gave [them]89-the misses leaf an opportunity of judging . "[2561-that young person with the rather pretty curls] [[My]0-i son]2562-my son 's [[my]0-i son]2562-my son till [he]2562-my son gets [him]2562-my son [a wife]3811-a wife , But [[my]0-i daughter]3014-my daughter 's [[my]0-i daughter]3014-my daughter all [her]3014-my daughter life . " And so , most frequently , is "[3014-my daughter] [[my]0-i sister]3017-my sister . " But not in this case . It could not be ; [they]89-the misses leaf never expected it would . When on here rare visits to [town]3838-town [Hilary]91-hilary called at [Russell Square]4341-russell square [she]91-hilary always found [Mrs. Ascott]99-ascott handsomely dressed , dignified , and gracious . Not in the slightest degree uncivil or unsisterly , but gracious — perhaps a thought too gracious . Most condescendingly anxious that [she]91-hilary should stay to luncheon , and eat and drink the best [the house]344-the house afforded , but never by any chance inviting [her]91-hilary to stay to dinner . Consequently , as [Mr. Ascott]97-ascott was always absent in [the city]1745-the city until dinner , [Hilary]91-hilary did not see [him]97-ascott for months together , and [[her]91-hilary brother - in - law]4344-her brother - in - law was , [she]91-hilary declared , no more to [her]91-hilary than [any other man upon ' Change]4345-any other man upon ' change , or [the man in the moon]4346-the man in the moon , or [the Great Mogul]4347-the great mogul . [[His]97-ascott wife]4348-his wife spoke little about [him]97-ascott . After a few faint , formal questions concerning [Richmond]27-richmond affairs , somehow [her]91-hilary conversation always recurred to [her]91-hilary own : the dinners [she]91-hilary had been at , those [she]91-hilary was going to give ; [[her]91-hilary carriages]4349-her carriages , clothes , jewelry , and so on . [She]91-hilary was altogether [a very great lady]4350-a very great lady , and [Hilary]91-hilary , as [she]91-hilary avouched laughingly — it was , in this case , better to laugh than to grieve — felt [an exceedingly small person beside [her]91-hilary]4351-an exceedingly small person beside her . Nevertheless [Mrs. Ascott]99-ascott showed no unkindness — nay , among the various changes that matrimony had produced in [her]91-hilary , [her]91-hilary temper appeared rather to have improved than otherwise ; there was now seldom any trace of that touchy sharpness which used to be called "[3014-my daughter] poor [Selina]92-selina 's way . " And yet [Hilary]91-hilary never quitted [the house]344-the house without saying to [herself]91-hilary , with a sigh , the old phrase , "[92-selina] [Poor Selina]92-selina ! " Thus , in the inevitable consequences of things , [her]91-hilary visits to [Russell Square]3-russell square became fewer and fewer ; [she]91-hilary kept them up as a duty , not exacting any return , for [she]91-hilary felt that was impossible , though still keeping up the ghostly shadow of sisterly intimacy . Nevertheless [she]91-hilary knew well it was but a shadow ; that the only face that looked honest , glad welcome , or that [she]91-hilary was honestly glad to see in [[[her]91-hilary brother - in - law]4344-her brother - in - law 's house]4354-her brother - in - law 's house was [the under house - maid]4355-the under house - maid , [Elizabeth Hand]94-elizabeth . Contrary to all expectations , [Mrs. Ascott]99-ascott had consented to take [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth into [her]99-ascott service . With many stipulations and warnings never to presume on past relations , never even to mention [Stowbury]2-stowbury , on pain of instant dismissal — still , [she]99-ascott did take [her]94-elizabeth , and [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth staid . At every one of [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's visits , lying in wait in [the bed chamber]4356-the bed chamber , or on the staircase , or creeping up at the last minute to open the hall door , was sure to appear [the familiar face]4357-the familiar face , beaming all over . Little conversation passed between [them]4358-them — [Mrs. Ascott]99-ascott evidently disliked it ; still [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth looked well and happy , and when [Miss Hilary]91-hilary told [her]94-elizabeth so [she]94-elizabeth always silently smiled . But this story must tell the whole truth which lay beneath that fond acquiescing smile . [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth was certainly in good health , being well fed , well housed , and leading on the whole an easy life ; happy , too , when [she]94-elizabeth looked at [Miss Hilary]91-hilary . But [her]94-elizabeth migration from [[Mrs. Jones]153-mrs. jones 's lodgings]4359-mrs. jones 's lodgings to [this grand mansion]4360-this grand mansion had not been altogether the translation from Purgatory to [Paradise]58-paradise that [some]3961-some would have supposed . [The author of this simple story having — unfortunately for it — never been in domestic service , especially in [the great houses of [London]1-london]4363-the great houses of london]4362-the author of this simple story having — unfortunately for it — never been in domestic service , especially in the great houses of london , does not pretend to describe the ins and outs of [their]4358-them "[92-selina] high life below stairs ; " to repeat kitchen conversations , to paint the humors of [[the servants]4364-the servants ' hall]4365-the servants ' hall — [the butler]4366-the butler and [housekeeper]4367-housekeeper getting tipsy together , [the cook]4368-the cook courting [the policeman]4369-the policeman , and [the footman]4370-the footman making love successively to [every house - maid]4371-every house - maid and [ladys'-maid]4372-ladys'-maid . [Some writers]4373-some writers have depicted all this , whether faithfully or not [they]4373-some writers know best ; but [the present writer]4374-the present writer declines to attempt any thing of the kind . [Her]4374-the present writer business is solely with [one domestic]4375-one domestic , [the country girl who came unexpectedly into this new world of [London]1-london servant - life]4376-the country girl who came unexpectedly into this new world of london servant - life — a world essentially [its]4377-its own , and a life of which [the upper classes]4378-the upper classes are as ignorant as [they]4378-the upper classes are of what goes on in [Madagascar]59-madagascar and [Otabeite]194-otabeite . This fact was the first which struck [the unsophisticated Elizabeth]94-elizabeth . [She]94-elizabeth , who had been brought up in a sort of feudal relationship to [[her]94-elizabeth dear mistresses]4379-her dear mistresses , was astonished to find [the domestics of [Russell Square]3-russell square]4380-the domestics of russell square banded together into [a community which , in spite of [their]4380-the domestics of russell square personal bickerings and jealousies , ended in alliance offensive and defensive against the superior powers]4381-a community which , in spite of their personal bickerings and jealousies , ended in alliance offensive and defensive against the superior powers , whom [they]4380-the domestics of russell square looked upon as [[their]4380-the domestics of russell square natural enemies]4382-their natural enemies . [Invisible enemies]4383-invisible enemies , certainly ; for "[4127-master] [master]4127-master " [they]4380-the domestics of russell square hardly ever saw ; and , excepting [[the ladys]4384-the ladys ' maid]4385-the ladys ' maid , were mostly as ignorant of "[92-selina] missis . " [The housekeeper]4386-the housekeeper was the middle link between [the two estates]4387-the two estates — [the person with whom all business was transacted , and to whom all complaints had to be made]4388-the person with whom all business was transacted , and to whom all complaints had to be made . Beyond being sometimes talked over , generally in a quizzical , depreciatory , or condemnatory way , [the heads of [the establishment]4390-the establishment]4389-the heads of the establishment were no more to [[their]4389-the heads of the establishment domestics]4290-their domestics than [the people who paid wages]4392-the people who paid wages , and exacted in return certain duties , which most of [them]4389-the heads of the establishment made as small as possible , and escaped whenever [they]4389-the heads of the establishment could . If this be an exaggerated picture of a state of things perhaps in degree inevitable — and yet it should not be , for it is the source of incalculable evil , this dividing of [a house]1174-a house against itself — if [I]92-selina have in any way said what is not true , [I]92-selina would that [some intelligent "[92-selina] voice from the kitchen]4394-some intelligent " voice from the kitchen " would rise up and tell [us]4395-us what is true , and whether it be possible on either side to find means of amending what so sorely needs reformation . [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth sometimes wanted [Tom Cliffe]132-tom to do this — to "[4127-master] write a book , " which [he]132-tom , [eager young malcontent]4396-eager young malcontent , was always threatening to do , upon the evils of society , and especially the tyranny of [the upper classes]4378-the upper classes . [Tom Cliffe]132-tom was the only person to whom [she]94-elizabeth imparted [her]94-elizabeth troubles and perplexities : how different [her]94-elizabeth life was from that [she]94-elizabeth had been used to ; how among [[her]94-elizabeth fellow - servants]4398-her fellow - servants there was [not one who did not seem to think and act in a manner totally opposed to every thing [she]94-elizabeth had learned from [Miss Hilary]91-hilary]4399-not one who did not seem to think and act in a manner totally opposed to every thing she had learned from miss hilary . How consequently [she]94-elizabeth [herself]94-elizabeth was teased , bullied , threatened , or at best "[4127-master] sent to [Coventry]60-coventry , " from morning till night . "[4127-master] [I]0-i am quite alone , [Tom]132-tom — [I]0-i am , indeed , " said [she]0-i , almost crying , the first Sunday night when [she]0-i met [him]132-tom accidentally in going to [church]396-church , and , in [her]0-i dreary state of mind , was exceedingly glad to see [him]132-tom . [He]132-tom consoled [her]0-i , and even went to [church]396-church with [her]0-i , half promising to do the same next Sunday , and calling [her]0-i "[92-selina] [a good little Christian]2569-a good little christian , who almost inclined [him]132-tom to be [a Christian]2570-a christian too . " And so , with the vague feeling that [she]0-i was doing [him]132-tom good and keeping [him]132-tom out of harm — [that lad who had so much that was kindly and nice about [him]132-tom]4402-that lad who had so much that was kindly and nice about him — [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth consented , not exactly to an appointment , but [she]0-i told [him]132-tom what were [her]0-i "[2569-a good little christian] Sundays out , " and [the church]4403-the church [she]0-i usually attended , if [he]132-tom liked to take the chance of [her]0-i being [there]3030-there . [Alack]195-alack ! [she]0-i had so few pleasures ; [she]0-i so seldom got even a breath of outside air — it was not thought necessary for [servants]1052-servants . The only hour [she]0-i was allowed out was the church - going on alternate Sunday evenings . How pleasant it was to creep out then , and see [Tom]132-tom waiting for [her]0-i under [the opposite trees]4406-the opposite trees , dressed so smart and gentlemanlike , looking so handsome and so glad to see [her]0-i — [her]0-i , [the poor countrified Elizabeth , who was quizzed incessantly by [[her]0-i fellow - servants]4398-her fellow - servants]4407-the poor countrified elizabeth , who was quizzed incessantly by her fellow - servants on [her]0-i oddness , plainness , and stupidity . [Tom]132-tom did not seem to think [her]0-i stupid , for [he]132-tom talked to [her]0-i of all [his]132-tom doings and plannings , vague and wild as those of [the young tailor]4409-the young tailor in "[2569-a good little christian] [Alton Locke]196-alton locke , " yet with a romantic energy about [them]4410-their that strongly interested [[his]132-tom companion]4411-his companion ; and [he]132-tom read [her]0-i [his]132-tom poetry , and addressed a few lines to [herself]0-i , beginning , "[196-alton locke] [Dearest and best]2571-dearest and best , [[my]0-i long familiar friend]2572-my long familiar friend ; " which was rather a poetical exaggeration , since [he]132-tom had altogether forgotten [her]0-i in the interval of [their]4410-their separation . But [she]0-i never guessed this ; and so [they]4410-their both clung to the early tie , making it out to be ten times stronger than it really was , as [people]3210-people do who are glad of any excuse for being fond of [one another]394-one another . [Tom]132-tom really was getting fond of [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth . [She]94-elizabeth touched the higher half of [his]132-tom nature — the spiritual and imaginative half . That [he]132-tom had it , though only [a working - man]4414-a working - man , and [she]94-elizabeth too , though only [a domestic servant]4415-a domestic servant , was most true : probably [many more of [their]4410-their class]4416-many more of their class have it than [we]4417-we are at all aware of . Therefore , [these two being special individuals]4418-these two being special individuals , were attracted by [each other]1168-each other ; [she]94-elizabeth by [him]132-tom , because [he]132-tom was clever , and [he]132-tom by [her]94-elizabeth , because [she]94-elizabeth was so good . For [he]132-tom had an ideal , poor [Tom Cliffe]132-tom ! and though it had been smothered and laid to sleep by a not too regular life , [it]132-tom woke up again under the kind , sincere eyes of this plain , simple - minded , honest [Elizabeth Hand]94-elizabeth . [He]132-tom knew [she]94-elizabeth was plain , and so old - fashioned in [her]94-elizabeth dress , that [Tom]132-tom , who was particular about such things , did not always like walking with [her]94-elizabeth : but [she]94-elizabeth was so interesting and true ; [she]94-elizabeth sympathized with [him]132-tom so warmly ; [he]132-tom found [her]94-elizabeth so unfailingly and unvaryingly good to [him]132-tom through all the little humors and pettishnesses that almost always accompany a large brain , a nervous temperament , and delicate health . [Her]94-elizabeth quietness soothed [him]132-tom , [her]94-elizabeth strength of character supported [him]132-tom ; [he]132-tom at once leaned on [her]94-elizabeth , and ruled over [her]94-elizabeth . As to [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's feelings toward [Tom]132-tom , they will hardly bear analyzing ; probably hardly any strong emotion will , especially one that is not sudden but progressive . [She]94-elizabeth admired [him]132-tom extremely , and yet [she]94-elizabeth was half sorry for [him]132-tom . Some things in [him]132-tom [she]94-elizabeth did not at all like , and tried heartily to amend . [His]132-tom nervous fancies , irritations , and vagaries [she]94-elizabeth was exceedingly tender over ; [she]94-elizabeth looked up to [him]132-tom , and yet took care of [him]132-tom ; this thought of [him]132-tom , and anxiety over [him]132-tom , became by degrees the habit of [her]94-elizabeth life . [People]3210-people love in so many different ways ; and perhaps that was the natural way in which [a woman like [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth]4421-a woman like elizabeth would love , or creep into love without knowing it , which is either the safest or the saddest form which the passion can assume . Thus things went on , till one dark , rainy Sunday night , walking round and round the inner circle of [the square]3596-the square , [Tom]132-tom expressed [his]132-tom feelings . At first , in somewhat high flown and poetical phrases , then melting into the one , eternally old and eternally new , "[196-alton locke] Do [you]2573-you love [me]0-i ? " followed by a long , long kiss , given under shelter of the umbrella , and in mortal fear of [the approaching policeman]4423-the approaching policeman ; who , however , never saw [them]4424-them , or saw [them]4424-them only as "[2573-you] pair of sweet - hearts"—too common an occurrence on [his]132-tom beat to excite any attention . But to [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth the whole thing was new , wonderful ; a bliss so far beyond any thing that had ever befallen [her]94-elizabeth simple life , and so utterly unexpected therein , that when [she]94-elizabeth went to [her]94-elizabeth bed that night [she]94-elizabeth cried like [a child]504-a child over the happiness of [Tom]132-tom 's loving [her]94-elizabeth , and [her]94-elizabeth exceeding unworthiness of the same . Then difficulties arose in [her]94-elizabeth mind . "[4131-no followers] [No followers]4131-no followers allowed , " was one of the strict laws of the Russell Square dynasty . Like many another law of that and of much higher dynasties it was only made to be broken ; for stray sweet - hearts were continually climbing down area railings , or over garden walls , or hiding [themselves]4426-themselves behind kitchen doors . Nay , to such an extent was the system carried out , [each servant]4427-each servant being , from self - interest , [a safe co - conspirator]4428-a safe co - conspirator , that very often when [Mr.]4429-mr. and [Mrs. Ascott]99-ascott went out to dinner , and [the old housekeeper]4430-the old housekeeper retired to bed , there were regular symposia held below stairs — nice little supper - parties , where all the viands in [the pantry]451-the pantry and the wines in [the cellar]4432-the cellar were freely used ; where [every domestic]4433-every domestic had [his]4429-mr. or [her]4434-her "[3998-young man] [young man]3998-young man " or "[3928-young woman] [young woman]3928-young woman , " and the goings - on , though not actually discreditable , were of the most lively kind . To be cognizant of these , and yet to feel that , as there was no actual wickedness going on , [she]94-elizabeth was not justified in "[3928-young woman] blabbing , " was a severe and perpetual trial to [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth . To join [them]4435-them , or bring [Tom]132-tom among [them]4435-them as [[her]94-elizabeth "[3928-young woman] young man]4436-her " young man , " was impossible . "[3928-young woman] No , [Tom]132-tom , " [she]94-elizabeth said , when [he]132-tom begged hard to come in one evening — for it was raining fast , and [he]132-tom had a bad cough — "[132-tom] No , [Tom]132-tom , [I]0-i ca n't let [you]132-tom . If [other folks]3767-other folks break the laws of [the house]344-the house , [I]0-i won't — [you]132-tom must go . [I]0-i can only meet [you]132-tom out of doors . " And yet to do this surreptitiously , just as if [she]94-elizabeth were ashamed of [him]132-tom , or as if there were something wrong in [their]4437-their being fond of [one another]394-one another , jarred upon [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's honest nature . [She]94-elizabeth did not want to make a show of [him]132-tom , especially to [[her]94-elizabeth fellow - servants]4398-her fellow - servants : [she]94-elizabeth had [the true woman]4440-the true woman 's instinct of liking to keep [her]4440-the true woman treasures all to [herself]94-elizabeth ; but [she]94-elizabeth had also [her]94-elizabeth sex 's natural yearning for sympathy in the great event of [a woman]669-a woman 's life . [She]94-elizabeth would have liked to have somebody unto whom [she]94-elizabeth could say , "[0-i] [Tom]132-tom has asked [me]0-i to marry [him]132-tom , " and who would have answered cordially , "[132-tom] It 's all right : [he]132-tom is [a good fellow]2579-a good fellow : [you]2580-you are sure to be happy . " Not that [she]94-elizabeth doubted this : but it would have been an additional comfort to have [a mother]3812-a mother 's blessing , or [a sister]2493-a sister 's , or even [a friend]3907-a friend 's , upon this strange and sweet emotion which had come into [her]94-elizabeth life . So long as it was thus kept secret there seemed a certain incompleteness and unsanctity about even [their]4445-their happy love . [Tom]132-tom did not comprehend this at all . [He]132-tom only laughed at [her]94-elizabeth for feeling so "[132-tom] nesh " ( that means tender , sensitive — but the word is almost unexplainable to other than [Stowbury]2-stowbury ears ) on the subject . [He]132-tom liked the romance and excitement of secret courtship — [men]3062-men often do ; rarely [women]3061-women , unless there is something in [them]3062-men not quite right , not entirely womanly . But [Tom]132-tom was very considerate , and though [he]132-tom called it "[2581-you] silly , " and took a little fit of crossness on the occasion , [he]132-tom allowed [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth to write to [mother]296-mother about [him]132-tom , and consented that on [her]94-elizabeth next holiday [she]94-elizabeth should go to [Richmond]27-richmond , in order to speak to [Miss Hilary]91-hilary on the same subject , and ask [her]94-elizabeth also to write to [Mrs. Hand]90-mrs. hand , stating how good and clever [Tom]132-tom was , and how exceedingly happy was [[Tom]132-tom 's [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth]4449-tom 's elizabeth . "[2581-you] And wo n't [you]2581-you come and fetch [me]0-i , [Tom]132-tom ? " asked [she]0-i , shyly . "[0-i] [I]0-i am sure [Miss Hilary]91-hilary would not object , nor [Miss Leaf]91-hilary neither . " [Tom]132-tom , protested [he]132-tom did not care two straws whether [they]4450-they objected or not ; [he]132-tom was [a man of twenty]4451-a man of twenty , in a good trade — [he]132-tom had lately gone back to the printing , and being [a clever workman]4452-a clever workman , earned capital wages . [He]132-tom had a right to choose whom [he]132-tom liked , and marry when [he]132-tom pleased . If [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth did n't care for [him]132-tom , [she]94-elizabeth might leave [him]132-tom alone . "[91-hilary] Oh , [Tom]132-tom ! " was all [she]0-i answered , with a strange gentleness that [no one]3371-no one could have believed would ever have come into the manner of [South Sea Islander]4-south sea islander . And quitting the subject then , [she]0-i afterward persuaded [him]132-tom , and not for the first time , into consenting to what [she]0-i thought right . There is something rather touching in [a servant]246-a servant 's holiday . It comes so seldom . [She]0-i must count on it for so long beforehand , and remember it for so long afterward . [This present writer]4455-this present writer owns to a strong sympathy with [the holiday - makers]4456-the holiday - makers on the grand gala - days of the English calendar . It is a pleasure to watch [the innumerable groups of [family folk]4458-family folk]4457-the innumerable groups of family folk , [little]4459-little , [children]308-children , and [prentice lands]4461-prentice lands . — "[132-tom] Dressed in all [their]2582-their best , To walk abroad with [Sally]197-sally . " And [the various "[197-sally] Sallys "]4462-the various " sallys " and [[their]4462-the various " sallys " corresponding swains]4463-their corresponding swains can hardly feel more regret than [she]0-i when it happens to be wet weather on Easter week or at [Whitsuntide]62-whitsuntide . Whit - Monday , the day when [Tom]132-tom escaped from [the printing - office]4464-the printing - office , and [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth got leave of absence for six hours , was as glorious a June day as well could be . As [the two young people]4465-the two young people perched [themselves]4465-the two young people on the top of [the Richmond omnibus]4466-the richmond omnibus and drove through [Kensington]40-kensington , [Hammersmith]63-hammersmith , [Turnham Green]64-turnham green , and over [Kew Bridge]65-kew bridge — [Tom]132-tom pointing out [all the places]4467-all the places , and giving much curious information about [them]4467-all the places — [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth thought there never was [a more beautiful country]4468-a more beautiful country , or a more lovely summer day : [she]94-elizabeth was , [she]94-elizabeth truly said , "[2583-a queen] as happy as [a Queen]2583-a queen . " Neverthless , when [the omnibus]4110-the omnibus stopped , [she]94-elizabeth , with great self - denial , insisted on getting rid of [Tom]132-tom for anytime . [She]94-elizabeth thought [Miss Hilary]91-hilary might not quite like [Tom]132-tom 's knowing where [she]94-elizabeth lived , or what [her]94-elizabeth occupation was , lest [he]132-tom might gossip about it to [Stowbury people]2378-stowbury people ; so [she]94-elizabeth determined to pay [her]94-elizabeth visit by [herself]94-elizabeth , and appointed to meet [him]132-tom at a certain hour on [Richmond Bridge]66-richmond bridge , over [which bridge]4471-which bridge [she]94-elizabeth watched [him]132-tom march sulkily , not without a natural pleasure that [he]132-tom should be so much vexed at losing [her]94-elizabeth company for an hour or two . But [she]94-elizabeth knew [he]132-tom would soon come to [himself]132-tom — as [he]132-tom did , before [he]132-tom had been half a mile on the road to [Hampton Court]67-hampton court , meeting [a young fellow [he]132-tom knew]4472-a young fellow he knew , and going with [him]132-tom over [that grand old palace]4473-that grand old palace , which furnished [them]4474-them with a subject at [their]4474-them next debating society , where [they]4474-them both came out very strong on the question of [hypocritical priests]4475-hypocritical priests and [obnoxious kings]4476-obnoxious kings , with especial reference to [Henry VIII]198-henry viii , and [Cardinal Wolsey]199-cardinal wolsey . Meanwhile [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth went in search of [the little shop — which [nobody]357-nobody need expect to find at [Richmond]27-richmond]4477-the little shop — which nobody need expect to find at richmond now — bearing the well - known name "[2583-a queen] [Janet Balquidder]200-janet balquidder . " Entering [it]3782-a shop , for there was no private door , [she]94-elizabeth saw , in the far corner above the curtained desk , the pretty curls of [[her]94-elizabeth dear]1959-her dear [Miss Hilary]91-hilary . [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth had long known that [[her]94-elizabeth mistress]431-her mistress "[200-janet balquidder] kept [a shop]3782-a shop , " and with the notions of gentility which are just as rife in [her]94-elizabeth class as in any other , had mourned bitterly over this fact . But when [she]94-elizabeth saw how fresh and well [the young lady]1573-the young lady looked , how busily and cheerfully [she]1573-the young lady seemed to work with [her]1573-the young lady great books before [her]1573-the young lady , and with what a composed grace and dignity [she]1573-the young lady came forward when asked for , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth secretly confessed that not even keeping [a shop]3782-a shop had made or could make the smallest difference in [Miss Hilary]91-hilary . [She]1573-the young lady [herself]1573-the young lady was much more changed . "[200-janet balquidder] Why , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , [I]0-i should hardly have known [you]94-elizabeth ! " was the involuntary exclamation of [[her]94-elizabeth late mistress]4483-her late mistress . [She]1573-the young lady certainly did look very nice ; not smart — for [her]1573-the young lady sober taste preferred quiet colors — but excessively neat and well - dressed . In [her]1573-the young lady new gown of gray "[94-elizabeth] coburg , " [her]1573-the young lady one handsome shawl , which had been honored several times by [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's wearing , [her]1573-the young lady white straw bonnet and white ribbons , underneath which the smooth black hair and soft eyes showed to great advantage , [she]1573-the young lady appeared , not "[4484-a lady"—a servant] like [a lady"—a servant]4484-a lady"—a servant can seldom do that let [her]4484-a lady"—a servant dress be ever so fine — but like [a thoroughly respectable , intelligent , and pleasant - faced young woman]4485-a thoroughly respectable , intelligent , and pleasant - faced young woman . And [her]1573-the young lady blushes came and went so fast , [she]1573-the young lady was so nervous and yet so beamingly happy , that [Miss Hilary]91-hilary soon suspected there was more in this visit than at first appeared . Knowing that with [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's great shyness the mystery would never come out in public , [she]91-hilary took an opportunity of asking [her]91-hilary to help [her]91-hilary in [the bedroom]4486-the bedroom , and there , with the folding - doors safely shut , discovered the whole secret . [Miss Hilary]91-hilary was a good deal surprised at first . [She]91-hilary had never thought of [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth as likely to get married at all — and to [Tom Cliffe]132-tom . "[4484-a lady"—a servant] Why , is n't [he]2585-he [a mere boy]2586-a mere boy ; ever so much younger than [you]2587-you are ? " "[2586-a mere boy] Three years . " "[2586-a mere boy] That is a pity — a great pity : [women]3061-women grow old so much faster than [men]3062-men . " "[0-i] [I]0-i know that , " said [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , somewhat sorrowfully . "[0-i] Besides , did [you]2587-you not tell [me]0-i [he]2585-he was very handsome and clever ? " "[2587-you] Yes : and [I]0-i 'm neither [the one]300-the one nor the other . [I]0-i have thought all that over too , many a time ; indeed [I]0-i have , [Miss Hilary]91-hilary . But [Tom]132-tom likes [me]0-i — or fancies [he]2585-he does . Do [you]2587-you think"—and the intense humility which true love always has , struck into [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's own conscious heart a conviction of how very true [this poor girl]4487-this poor girl 's love must be . "[2587-you] Do [you]2587-you think [he]2585-he is mistaken ? that [his]2585-he liking [me]0-i — [I]0-i mean in that sort of way — is quite impossible ? " "[2587-you] No , indeed , and [I]0-i never said it ; never thought it , " was the earnest reply . "[0-i] But consider ; three years younger than [yourself]2587-you ; handsomer and cleverer than [you]2587-you are — " . [Miss Hilary]91-hilary stopped ; it seemed so cruel to say such things , and yet [she]91-hilary felt bound to say them . [She]91-hilary knew [[her]91-hilary former "[2587-you] bower - maiden]4488-her former " bower - maiden " well enough to be convinced that if [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth were not happy in marriage [she]94-elizabeth would be worse than unhappy — might grow actually bad . "[2585-he] [He]2585-he loves [you]2587-you now ; [you]2587-you are sure of that ; but are [you]2587-you sure that [he]2585-he is [a thoroughly stable and reliable character]2591-a thoroughly stable and reliable character ? Do [you]2587-you believe [he]2585-he will love [you]2587-you always ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't tell . Perhaps — if [I]0-i deserved it , " said [poor Elizabeth]94-elizabeth . And , looking at the downcast eyes , at the thorough womanly sweetness and tenderness which suffused the whole face , [Hilary]91-hilary 's doubts began to melt away . [She]91-hilary thought how sometimes [men , captivated by inward rather than outward graces]4489-men , captivated by inward rather than outward graces , have fallen in love with [plain women]4490-plain women , or [women older than [themselves]4489-men , captivated by inward rather than outward graces]4491-women older than themselves , and actually kept to [their]4489-men , captivated by inward rather than outward graces attachment through life , with a fidelity rare as beautiful . Perhaps [this young fellow]4492-this young fellow , who seemed by all accounts superior to [[his]4492-this young fellow class]4276-his class — having had the sense to choose that pearl in an oyster - shell , [Elizabeth Hand]94-elizabeth — might also have the sense so appreciate [her]94-elizabeth , and go on loving [her]94-elizabeth to the end of [his]4492-this young fellow days , Anyhow , [he]4492-this young fellow loved [her]94-elizabeth now , and [she]94-elizabeth loved [him]4492-this young fellow ; and it was useless reasoning any more about it . "[0-i] Come , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , " cried [[her]94-elizabeth mistress]431-her mistress , cheerfully , "[94-elizabeth] [I]0-i have said all [my]0-i say , and now [I]0-i have only to give [my]0-i good wishes . If [Tom Cliffe]132-tom deserves [you]94-elizabeth , [I]0-i am sure [you]94-elizabeth deserve [him]132-tom , and [I]0-i should like to tell [him]132-tom so . " "[94-elizabeth] Should [you]94-elizabeth , [Miss Hilary]91-hilary ? " and with a visible brightening up [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth betrayed [Tom]132-tom 's whereabouts , and [her]94-elizabeth little conspiracy to bring [him]132-tom [here]389-here , and [her]94-elizabeth hesitation lest it might be "[94-elizabeth] intruding . " "[94-elizabeth] Not at all . Tell [him]132-tom to come at once . [I]0-i am not like [[my]0-i sister]3017-my sister ; [we]2593-we always allow ' [followers]2594-followers . ' [I]0-i think [a mistress]1063-a mistress stands in the relation of [a parent]2596-a parent , for the time being ; and that can not be a right or good love which is concealed from [her]1063-a mistress , as if it were a thing to be ashamed of . " "[0-i] [I]0-i think so too . And [I]0-i 'm not a bit ashamed of [Tom]132-tom , nor [he]132-tom of [me]0-i , " said [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , so energetically that [Miss Hilary]91-hilary smiled . "[132-tom] Very well ; take [him]132-tom to have [his]132-tom tea in [the kitchen]253-the kitchen , and then bring [him]132-tom up [stairs]3048-stairs to speak to [[my]0-i sister]3017-my sister and [me]0-i . " At that interview , which of course was rather trying , [Tom]132-tom acquitted [himself]132-tom to [every body]3430-every body 's satisfaction . [He]132-tom was manly , modest , self - possessed ; did not say much — [his]132-tom usual talkativeness being restrained by the circumstances of the case , and the great impression made upon [him]132-tom by [Miss Hilary]91-hilary , who , [he]132-tom afterward admitted to [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , "[2600-a real angel] was [a real angel]2600-a real angel , and [he]132-tom should write a poem upon [her]3017-my sister . " But the little [he]132-tom did say gave [the ladies]245-the ladies a very good impression of the intelligence and even refinement of [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's sweet - heart . And though [they]245-the ladies were sorry to see [him]132-tom look so delicate , still there was a something better than handsomeness in [his]132-tom handsome face , which made [them]245-the ladies not altogether surprised at [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth 's being so fond of [him]132-tom . As [she]94-elizabeth watched [the young couple]4498-the young couple down [Richmond Street]68-richmond street , in the soft summer twilight — [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth taking [Tom]132-tom 's arm , and [Tom]132-tom drawing up [his]132-tom stooping figure to its utmost extent , both a little ill - matched in height as [they]4498-the young couple were in some other things , but walking with that air of perfect confidence and perfect contentedness in each other which always betrays , to a quick eye , [those who have agreed to walk through the world]4499-those who have agreed to walk through the world together — [Miss Hilary]91-hilary turned from the window and sighed . Following [Miss Hilary]91-hilary 's earnest advice that every thing should be fair and open , [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth , on the very next day after that happy Whit - Monday , mustered up [her]94-elizabeth courage , asked permission to speak to [[her]94-elizabeth mistress]431-her mistress , and told [her]431-her mistress [she]94-elizabeth was going to be married to [Tom Cliffe]132-tom : not immediately , but in a year 's time or so , if all went well . [Mrs. Ascott]99-ascott replied sharply that it was no affair of [hers]99-ascott , and [she]99-ascott could not be troubled about it . For [her]99-ascott part [she]99-ascott thought , if [servants]1052-servants knew [their]1052-servants own advantages , [they]1052-servants would keep a good place when [they]1052-servants had it , and never get married at all . And then , saying [she]99-ascott had heard a good character of [her]94-elizabeth from [the housekeeper]4386-the housekeeper , [she]99-ascott offered [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth the place of [upper house - maid]4503-upper house - maid , [a young girl]4504-a young girl , [a protegee of [the housekeeper]4386-the housekeeper 's]4505-a protegee of the housekeeper 's , being substituted in [hers]94-elizabeth . "[132-tom] And when [you]2601-you have sixteen pounds a year , and somebody to do all [your]2601-you hard work for [you]2601-you , [I]0-i dare say [you]2601-you 'll think better of it , and not be so foolish as to go and get married . " But [Elizabeth]94-elizabeth had [her]94-elizabeth own private opinion on that matter .
